physicalSubstrateObject: small potted plant with green foliage in a ribbed yellow ceramic pot
contactUtilizationMethod: Pinch the pen near its tip with thumb, index, and middle finger, rest ring and little finger on the barrel, and perform precise wrist-controlled strokes.
substrateUtilizationMethod: Keep the pot upright on the table, steady it by lightly gripping the stem or rim with the non-dominant hand so the smooth ceramic side facing you becomes a vertical plane, then guide the pen tip in light taps or wrist-led strokes across that side.
expectedHapticFeedback: Oil paint on a large size canvas with a paint brush. With gentle pressure, the resistance increases smoothly with a subtle pushback sensation
harmony_explanation: Curved ceramic pot provides a midsize vertical surface that the pen can reliably touch whenever the virtual brush meets the canvas. Some curvature reduces consistency but size and stability still allow most contacts to coincide with visuals.
expressivity_explanation: The pot provides a broad surface, but the glazed ceramic is rigid and slick, offering almost no progressive resistance. Variation in stroke speed or pressure yields little tactile change, so canvas-like pushback is poorly conveyed.
realism_explanation: The ceramic pot provides a rigid, slick surface with no give, unlike a taut fabric canvas that offers slight compliance and texture. Size is also much smaller than a large canvas.

physicalSubstrateObject: white decorative rabbit statuette with textured lines

substrateUtilizationMethod: Hold the rabbit’s rear legs with the non-dominant hand so one flank is upright and stationary; sweep or dab the pen tip along that flat side using small controlled wrist motions.
expectedHapticFeedback: Oil paint on a large size canvas with a paint brush. With gentle pressure, the resistance increases smoothly with a subtle pushback sensation
harmony_explanation: Rabbit is very small; the single flank area is narrow and irregular. It is easy for pen to slip off or miss when sweeping larger virtual strokes, so visual-to-haptic timing will be hit-or-miss.
expressivity_explanation: Textured ridges on the statuette create some micro-variation, but the hard resin still lacks give. The limited flat area further restricts stroke length, reducing expressivity compared to a real canvas.
realism_explanation: Although the rabbit’s flank has some texture reminiscent of canvas weave, the statuette is hard resin and the available flat area is tiny, so resistance does not ramp smoothly as expected in brush-on-canvas interaction.

realism_explanation: The clamp provides a reasonably flat plastic plane that is wider than many other options, though still far smaller than a canvas. Surface is rigid and low-friction, so pushback is minimal but control of strokes is acceptable.

realism_explanation: Bottle side is slightly flexible plastic giving minimal yield—better than hard metal but still lacks the fabric texture and larger painting area of a canvas.

contactUtilizationMethod: Grip the wooden handle near its hole between thumb and first two fingers and sweep the wrist as though brushing paint.
substrateUtilizationMethod: Lay the tape measure flat on the table with its circular top exposed, then brush the broom bristles over the plastic face in smooth arcs.
expectedHapticFeedback: Oil paint on a large size canvas with a paint brush. With gentle pressure, the resistance increases smoothly with a subtle pushback sensation
harmony_explanation: The tape-measure face is roughly 6 cm across; this limited footprint makes it very easy to overshoot. Physical touch will often be absent when the virtual brush still appears to be on the canvas.
expressivity_explanation: Smooth ABS plastic disc offers almost no friction gradient; the area is only palm-sized, so strokes are truncated and variation with force is minimal.
realism_explanation: Surface is hard plastic and only a few centimetres wide, which limits stroke length and gives no elastic push-back. Interaction feels nothing like dragging a brush over canvas.

expressivity_explanation: A coin-sized mirror-smooth steel cap cannot deliver any spatial or force variation; strokes immediately leave the surface and feel like hitting a rigid puck—no resemblance to painting on canvas.
realism_explanation: Only a tiny, mirror-smooth metal disk is contacted; zero lateral travel and no compliance. The sensation is nothing like painting on canvas.

expressivity_explanation: Large taut fabric panel behaves similarly to canvas: moderate texture, broad area, and progressive resistance as pressure compresses padding behind the mesh. Enables rich variation with stroke speed and force.
realism_explanation: Large vertical fabric plane allows long strokes and provides mild give similar to canvas, giving the best approximation so far. Still, sponge lacks bristle feedback and backrest is more cushioned than taut canvas, reducing realism.
